text: Your package has been delayed. Click here to reschedule delivery: http://fedex-tracker.info
explanation: The URL is fake—legitimate companies use their official domain like fedex.com.

text: Instagram asks to access your photos so you can post them directly.
explanation: Photo-sharing apps typically need photo access—this is expected behavior.

text: This free flashlight app needs access to your contacts and microphone.
explanation: Flashlight apps don’t need contacts or mic access—it's a red flag.

text: An email from 'Apple Support' says your account was suspended. Link: http://apple.support-logins.net
explanation: That’s a spoofed domain—Apple would never use a URL like that.

text: Your Google account was signed in on a new device. Check activity: https://myaccount.google.com/security
explanation: That’s Google’s real domain and a common security alert.

text: A VPN app asks for access to your browsing history and app usage.
explanation: A privacy tool shouldn't track you—this contradicts its purpose.

text: A new app asks for notification access so it can alert you to messages.
explanation: This is normal for messaging or utility apps.

text: “Congratulations! You’ve won a $1,000 gift card. Click to claim your prize!”
explanation: Unsolicited prizes with links are classic phishing bait.

text: A coworker sent you a shared doc, but the email says: 'shared via g00gle.docs.work'
explanation: That's a fake domain. The real one is google.com.

text: The Uber app requests GPS access to track your ride location.
explanation: GPS access is expected for a transportation app.

text: This app asks for camera access to scan barcodes.
explanation: Barcode scanners need camera access—it’s a valid permission.

text: A music player wants to access your text messages and call logs.
explanation: Music apps don’t need access to messages or call data.

text: You receive an email that appears to be from your bank, but the sender's address is 'security@bank-alerts.xyz'.
explanation: Real banks use their official domains—.xyz is a red flag.

text: This fitness app requests access to your step count from your phone’s health system.
explanation: Fitness apps often use that data to track health goals.

text: An app asks to access your clipboard.
explanation: Clipboard access can be abused to steal copied passwords or info.

text: An email says your PayPal account is locked. The link goes to 'paypalsecure-verification.com'
explanation: That’s a spoofed site—PayPal only uses paypal.com.

text: A calculator app asks to track your location in the background.
explanation: Calculators don’t need location—suspicious behavior.

text: A weather app asks for location access while using the app.
explanation: That’s expected so it can show your local forecast.

text: This app wants permission to record audio and run in the background 24/7.
explanation: Always-on recording is a major privacy risk.

text: You get an email with a fake invoice from a company you've never heard of.
explanation: Scam invoices are a common phishing tactic.

text: An app says 'We need admin access to optimize performance.'
explanation: Most apps don’t need admin rights—this could be malware.

text: Microsoft sends you a login alert from a new location via: https://account.microsoft.com
explanation: That’s a valid domain used for real Microsoft account alerts.

text: An email says 'Click here to view your tax refund status' and links to 'irs-tax-check.org'
explanation: That’s not an official IRS domain—it’s a phishing trap.

text: An app requests file storage access so you can upload documents.
explanation: That’s expected for apps like Google Drive or Dropbox.

text: A random email asks you to 'verify your account info immediately or it will be deleted.'
explanation: Urgency + threats are classic phishing red flags.

text: An app asks for access to accessibility services, but it's not a tool that needs them.
explanation: Malware often abuses accessibility permissions to gain control.

text: A photo editor asks for camera and photo library access.
explanation: That’s necessary for editing and saving your pictures.

text: You get a Zoom invite from an unknown email and the link is 'zoomstartmeeting.co'
explanation: That’s not a Zoom domain—zoom.us is the only valid one.

text: An app wants SMS access so it can auto-fill OTP codes for login.
explanation: Some apps use this for convenience, though it should be optional.

text: You’re offered a free Bitcoin giveaway—just enter your wallet address!
explanation: Scams often promise free crypto in exchange for your info.

text: You receive a message from your boss asking you to buy gift cards ASAP—but it's from a Gmail address.
explanation: This is a common impersonation scam using personal email addresses.

text: Your Wi-Fi analyzer app requests location access to find nearby networks.
explanation: Location is needed to scan for Wi-Fi SSIDs on newer devices.

text: An email says 'we noticed suspicious activity' but doesn’t include your name and links to a strange domain.
explanation: Generic messages and suspicious links = phishing.

text: Your phone’s OS update wants full access to system settings.
explanation: Operating system updates need system-level access to function.

text: An app requests Bluetooth access to connect to nearby devices.
explanation: Common for fitness trackers, speakers, and smart devices.

text: An email from IT support asks for your password to 'verify your account.'
explanation: No legit IT staff will ask for your password—ever.

text: An app wants to auto-launch at startup and monitor your app usage.
explanation: That’s excessive unless clearly necessary—many malware apps do this.

text: Your password manager app wants access to autofill login fields.
explanation: That’s expected behavior for password managers.

text: A free game app wants access to your call logs and contact list.
explanation: Games don’t need your private contact or call data.

text: An email appears to be from Netflix, but says 'Your payment failed' and links to 'netflixbilling-help.com'
explanation: That’s a fake domain—real Netflix links come from netflix.com.

text: Your smart home app wants access to your local network.
explanation: That’s needed to control smart devices like lights and thermostats.

text: A productivity app asks to access your calendar and events.
explanation: This allows it to manage meetings or schedule tasks.

text: A game wants location access to serve local ads and offers.
explanation: Location for ads isn't necessary—opt-in at best.

text: A social media app asks to access your camera, mic, and storage.
explanation: These are common permissions for posting media content.

text: An app asks to disable your phone’s lock screen and take admin privileges.
explanation: Very dangerous—only trusted security tools should have this access.

text: A photo gallery app wants access to your media files.
explanation: That’s normal—it can’t show or organize photos otherwise.

text: A streaming app wants to record your screen and audio.
explanation: This could be used to spy—usually unnecessary for streaming.

text: A healthcare app wants access to your step count and heart rate.
explanation: That’s standard functionality for health tracking apps.

text: A message says your Windows license is expired—call this number immediately.
explanation: That’s a tech support scam—never call unverified numbers.
